videos.title: No Woman No Cry üå¥ | Bob Marley | Reggae Guitar Duo üáØüá≤
videos.description:
No Woman No Cry by Bob Marley üå¥üáØüá≤  
A reggae classic arranged for acoustic nylon unplugged guitar.

Relaxed island vibes, soulful melody, and timeless reggae feel.
Perfect for reggae lovers, guitarists, and Bob Marley fans.

Jamming with one of my good friends as a duo, and I hope you like jamming too. Two nylon classical guitars is a different experience than the norm, but it does work perfectly, since they are like giant ukuleles, furthering the island vibe. Not over produced, which I am certainly guilty of doing sometimes. One camera, one Rode Cam mic, sweeteners on the master fader, that's it. I actually like the birds chirping in the background. Sorry for summer vibes in the winter time, but I like to pretend. I hate the winter. Just trying to get the word out about this video that never got any traction but I think it is very good, so please like, share and comment what your favorite reggae song is.

videos.title: Registro ‚Äì Antonio Lauro | Classical Guitar Short
videos.description:
Registro by Antonio Lauro, from Suite Venezolana No. 1, performed on classical guitar. The piece is peaceful, experimental and new age sounding. It reminds me of Claude Debussy a little bit, with emphasis on beauty over excitement, and emphasis on parallel motion over counterpoint (contrary melodic movement). I like when classical pieces have a slight jazz touch to it, as there are minor 7th chords that aren't resolved in the classical sense.

üé∏ Classical guitar short
üéº Latin American repertoire | Venezuelan üáªüá™ classical guitar
üìç Antonio Lauro (1917‚Äì1986)

videos.title: The Essential Beginner's Guitar Songbook - A Progressive Collection
videos.description:
Pages: 108 - A substantial bundle deal - 88% cheaper than individual purchases
Songs: 59 (Famous Public Domain Songs)

A collection of famous public domain songs mixed with a few of my original guitar studies. An excellent resource to have for a beginner guitarist with beginner friendly notation. It does an excellent job at slowly getting more difficult. Even if you are an experienced guitarist, it is still useful if you want to up your traditional notation and theory game.

Get it now: https://www.sheetmusicdirect.com/se/ID_No/1921418/Product.aspx

This anthology doesn't avoid traditional sheet music notation, but instead has a highly scaffolded approach, allowing for the ability to learn sheet music while removing tedium, frustration and overly boring pieces.

As a guitar teacher for over a decade, lack of high-quality sheet music is the biggest problem. Sure there are low quality songs on the internet for free, but after a couple months of playing, they begin to not improve talent, insight, accuracy, discipline or theory advancement. Asking someone to buy one song at a time has a lot of friction and tedium, so I created this songbook. I gurantee you will enjoy it and feel like there is little to no prerequisite skills required to use it.

Features:
Beginner friendly
Guitar Tablature (TAB)
Chord diagrams
Chord names
Often has lyrics when appropriate
Large appealing fonts
Slurs (Pull-offs, hammer-ons, slides and bends)
Often has letter names inside note heads, perfect for aiding in sight-reading and theory.
Chord voicings that take the main melody, difficulty, originality, and beauty into consideration.

videos.title: Exotic Music Live Livestream üé∏üåç | Global Guitar Journey (Indian, Persian, Reggae, Classical & More)
videos.description:
This long-form Exotic Music live livestream is a global musical journey across cultures, styles, and traditions‚Äîperformed entirely on guitar. Throughout the stream, I explore sounds and ideas inspired by Indian, Egyptian, Persian, Chinese, Brazilian Choro, Reggae, as well as Western Classical, Romantic, Minimalism, and Lo-fi influences.

Rather than focusing on one genre, this livestream blends world music concepts, improvisation, modal harmony, rhythmic exploration, and tonal color into a continuous, immersive listening experience. Many sections are improvisatory, drawing on traditional scales, modes, and rhythmic feels from different cultures, while others reflect composed or stylistic approaches from classical and modern traditions.

This is a long-form livestream, ideal for:

Background listening

Studying or relaxing

Exploring global music influences

Guitar inspiration and improvisation

Fans of world music, ambient music, and experimental guitar

üé∂ Styles & Influences Featured:

Indian classical‚Äìinspired modes and drones

Egyptian & Middle Eastern tonal colors

Persian melodic ideas

Chinese pentatonic textures

Brazilian Choro rhythms

Reggae grooves

Western Classical & Romantic harmony

Minimalism and Lo-fi atmospheres

üé∏ Instrument: Guitar
üì∫ Format: Long live-stream / extended performance
üåç Theme: Global / Exotic / World Music Fusion

If you enjoy world music, exotic scales, guitar improvisation, long ambient streams, or cross-cultural musical exploration, this livestream is for you.

üëâ Consider liking, subscribing, or leaving a comment about which culture or sound stood out most to you.

videos.description:
This dreamy F Lydian backing track is designed for guitarists looking to explore modal improvisation, melodic soloing, and ambient phrasing. While centered around F Lydian, this track can also be approached from C Major or A Minor, depending on note choice and tonal emphasis. Putting a lot of reverb and delay effects on is always a fun time.

Perfect for:
üé∏ Guitar improvisation
üé∏ Modal practice (Lydian sound)
üé∏ Ambient & cinematic guitar
üé∏ Songwriting and creative flow
üé∏ Practice, warm-ups, and jamming

This backing track leaves plenty of space for guitar, making it ideal for lead playing, phrasing practice, and expressive melodic ideas.

You can check out the live steam video of the making of this backing track:
https://www.youtube.com/live/KF_cwKoYSMc

üéº Intuitive Guitar Sheet Music, TABs & Learning Resources

videos.title: HYPED Synth-Metal Backing Track ‚ö° Night / Party Energy
videos.description:
Jam over this C# Harmonic Minor backing track designed for guitarists, featuring a dark industrial EDM synth metal groove and an on-screen scale chart for practice, improvisation, and soloing. You will most likely need distortion and effects since this is one of the powerful sounding tracks I've ever encountered. Rest in power chords headphone users.

Perfect for guitarists working on harmonic minor shapes, exotic metal phrasing, neoclassical runs, and modern synth-metal tones.

My goal is to create a backing track for every key and mode, which is ambitious. There are 12/24 keys in music but if you count modes and the various minor scale, it can add up to be a lot. My goal is to create more uncommon scales and uncommon genres for backing tracks since that fills a gap that Youtube doesn't have.

videos.title: C# Harmonic Minor Backing Track | Industrial EDM Synth Metal | Guitar Scale Chart
videos.description:
Jam over this C# Harmonic Minor backing track designed for guitarists, featuring a dark industrial EDM synth metal groove and an on-screen scale chart for practice, improvisation, and soloing. You will most likely need distortion and effects since this is one of the powerful sounding tracks I've ever encountered. Rest in power chords headphone users.

Perfect for guitarists working on harmonic minor shapes, exotic metal phrasing, neoclassical runs, and modern synth-metal tones.

My goal is to create a backing track for every key and mode, which is ambitious. There are 12/24 keys in music but if you count modes and the various minor scale, it can add up to be a lot. My goal is to create more uncommon scales and uncommon genres for backing tracks since that fills a gap that Youtube doesn't have.

videos.title: Nocturne Op. 37 No. 1 (Chopin) ‚Äì Guitar Arrangement | Sheet Music TAB & MIDI Visualization
videos.description:
This is an excellent tool for an aspiring guitarist to play a difficult yet beautiful piece of music: Chopin's Nocturne Op. 37 No. 1 arranged for guitar. This one of kind unique arrangement features guitar TAB, chord names, composer indications and articulations all with dark mode visuals so that your eyes aren't strained. My vision is to create "real guitar hero"! Fun yet wholesome, where all the tedious parts have already been done for you.

TAB & Sheet Music PDF: https://www.sheetmusicdirect.com/se/ID_No/1375003/Product.aspx

üé∏ About This Guitar Arrangement
‚Ä¢ Solo classical guitar transcription
‚Ä¢ Inspired by the expressive rubato and lyricism of Chopin‚Äôs original piano work
‚Ä¢ Balanced between faithful harmony and idiomatic guitar voicings
‚Ä¢ High-quality audio/video with synchronized MIDI + sheet music scroll

üìú Sheet Music & MIDI Scroll
This video includes a full sheet-music scroll to follow along easily, plus a MIDI representation that highlights notes, articulations, and timing.
Perfect for learning, studying, or enjoying a visual performance.

üéº About the Piece
Composed in 1839, Chopin‚Äôs Nocturne Op. 37 No. 1 is known for its haunting melody, rich harmonies, and deeply emotive contrast.
Hearing it on guitar brings out new warmth, intimacy, and resonance not possible on piano.

If you enjoy classical guitar arrangements of Romantic piano music, check out the rest of my performances and transcriptions.

videos.description:
Enter a hypnotic synthwave atmosphere with this B minor backing track ‚Äî perfect for guitar, keys, production inspiration, improvisation, or zoning out into a creative trance. There is a guitar scale chart on the screen in the key of B minor (aeolian) / D Major (Ionian) with beautiful visuals that allow you to get into the zone of creativity. 
Warm pads, retro arps, and a steady trance-inspired pulse create an immersive environment to explore melody and tone. This reminds me a bit of lo-fi study playlist. I tell you, I want to grind at work when listening to this! Let's go!

videos.title: Chopin ‚Äì Waltz No. 2 Op. 69 (Metal Guitar Version) | Heavy Classical Fusion Cover
videos.description:
Experience Fr√©d√©ric Chopin‚Äôs iconic ‚ÄúWaltz No. 2, Op. 69‚Äù reimagined as an intense metal guitar instrumental arrangement. This fusion cover blends the elegance of Romantic-era piano music with modern distortion and powerful expressive phrasing. If you enjoy classical-metal crossovers, neoclassical guitar, or creative re-arrangements of timeless pieces, this performance is for you.

Chopin‚Äôs Waltz in B minor is one of his most lyrical and emotional works, originally written for solo piano around 1829. It combines melancholy melody with graceful waltz rhythms‚Äîperfect material for a dramatic metal transformation. This arrangement highlights the harmony and melody with scrolling guitar TAB and sheet music, making it a great resource for aspiring guitarists that want an extreme challenge, though I did rearrange the music into a easier guitar key.

This is a great example why I love edge of break up distortion tones; it will only distort if I play loud enough and if I engage my Helix Line 6 expression pedal. This is also why I love the Helix, I don't have to be committed to one tone, distortion or EQ, I can weave seamlessly in and out of things. If I was simply super distorted the whole time, then a lot of these fragile chords would have sounded bad.

Full Video Here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F-o_OarX_AU&feature=youtu.be Chopin ‚Äì Waltz No. 2 Op. 69 (Metal Guitar Version) | Heavy Classical Fusion Cover

Chopin arrangement PDF can be purchased here: https://www.sheetmusicdirect.com/se/ID_No/1273007/Product.aspx

videos.title: How to Play Moonlight Sonata (Beethoven) for Guitar - Sheet Music TAB Scroll
videos.description:
This one is a hard one!

You can purchase the PDFs I make here:
https://www.sheetmusicplus.com/title/moonlight-sonata-piano-sonata-no-14-digital-sheet-music/22417414

I added these sheet music scroll videos so that potential customers could preview what my sheet music looks like and roughly sounds like using MIDI data. The formatting did get a bit messed up but it's close enough to get the idea. The MIDI data obviously leads to a pretty emotionless and robotic recording, but hopefully that'll spark interest to perform it.

The octave is lower than what it is supposed to be. Oops but I kept it because guitar can't achieve that octave anyways, so you get a nice deep bass line going sometimes. I was wondering if I should have put chord diagrams? I didn't because it risks being over simplified and over complicated at the same time.

#MoonlightSonata #Beethoven #BeethovenGuitar #ClassicalGuitar #GuitarTutorial #GuitarLesson #HowToPlayGuitar #GuitarPlayAlong #SheetMusicVideo #ScrollingSheetMusic #GuitarArrangement #GuitarCover #RealGuitarHero #FingerstyleGuitar #ClassicalMusic #PianoToGuitar #MusicEducation #LearnGuitar #GuitarPractice #GuitarSkills #MusicVisualization #GuitarTabs #GuitarNotation #MoonlightSonataGuitar #GuitarCommunity #guitartabs

videos.title: How to Play Amazing Grace  - Sheet Music Scroll
videos.description:
I added these sheet music Youtube videos so that potential customers could preview what my sheet music looks like and roughly sounds like using MIDI data. The MIDI data obviously leads to a pretty emotionless and robotic recording, but hopefully that'll spark interest to perform it. 

https://www.sheetmusicdirect.com/en-US/se/ID_No/1220619/Product.aspx

Amazing Grace  - Sheet Music Scroll

Teach yourself Amazing Grace with this video. You may want to click the cog wheel on youtube to switch to 1080 resolution, otherwise it is a bit blurry. The chords are harmonized differently to be idiomatic for guitar. The circles in the tab mean 2 beats. The computer to not play the grace notes well unfortunately (just sounded like 8ths but they should be nearly as fast as possible) but that is your job as a musician!

videos.title: D Dorian Backing Track Jam with Scale Chart
videos.description:
Sorry, it does have a key change. I couldn't resist because otherwise I was afraid it would be too monotonous. Another way of thinking about it is that you play what you just play but two frets lower on everything for C dorian. 

This beginner-friendly D Dorian backing track comes with a simple scale chart to help you learn the mode and start improvising right away. It is almost like a giant guitar tab.

Sometimes I was making mistakes with it, but it still kind of worked because it is quirky to begin with, so have fun!

I decided to go with no color coding on the scale this time because it is modal. That is why I just tried to make it look cool, similar to how websites sometimes have a dark mode feature.

GigSalad: https://www.gigsalad.com/intuitive_minds_united_aberdeen

Date Composed: Around 1890

Published: 1893

Instrumentation: Solo piano

Style: Impressionist / Avant-garde / Minimalist

The term "Gnossienne" was invented by Satie. It doesn‚Äôt exist in traditional musical terminology. Scholars speculate the name may refer to:

Knossos, the ancient Minoan city (relating to Greek mythology and ritual dance ‚Äî particularly the myth of the Minotaur and the labyrinth).

Or it may reflect a personal, esoteric invention by Satie, meant to suggest something mystical, archaic, or ritualistic.

Satie often rebelled against traditional forms ‚Äî the "Gnossiennes" don‚Äôt follow classical structures like sonatas or waltzes, and even the time signatures and bar lines are sometimes missing.

He had recently broken ties with the Schola Cantorum (a conservative music school), and was exploring a radically new aesthetic: sparse textures, ambiguous harmony, and a rejection of Romantic excess.

These pieces reflect his interest in the mystical and the occult, as well as his fascination with Eastern modes and medieval scales.

Tempo: Generally marked Lent (slow)

No bar lines: The rhythm is meant to feel free and fluid.

Modal harmony: It often leans on the Dorian mode and unusual voice leading, creating a sense of timelessness.

Expressive markings: Like many of Satie's works, the piece includes whimsical, surreal, or poetic instructions in French (e.g., "Avec √©tonnement" ‚Äì "With astonishment").

Musical minimalism before it was a defined movement

Emotional ambiguity ‚Äî it‚Äôs neither sad nor happy, just strangely suspended

Free rhythm and floating melody, predating ideas we see later in Debussy and even ambient music

üìö Legacy
The Gnossiennes became some of Satie‚Äôs most popular piano pieces, alongside the Gymnop√©dies.

They have influenced countless composers, from Debussy and Ravel to John Cage and Philip Glass.

Gnossienne No. 3 is often performed in solo recitals and is loved for its hypnotic, meditative quality.

It has also been used in films, dance, and art installations, thanks to its atmospheric mood.

videos.title: G Minor / B‚ô≠ Major ‚Äî Upbeat Jazz Backing Track (Happy & Bright)
videos.description:
This upbeat jazz backing track in G minor / B‚ô≠ major offers a happy, energetic groove that‚Äôs great for jamming and improvisation practice. It is in jazz lead style scrolling sheet music notation that guitarist prefer. It is medium level difficulty because it is a hard key, and there are no chord diagrams, so you'll have to know chords by heart. Though a much easier way to enjoy this is to simply play pentatonic scale at fret 3 (G minor Bb Major)

1. It is in the key of G minor for the most part except the C major chords, and even playing an Eb over those probably wouldn't be the end of the world.
2. You can simplify chords. D7b9 can simply be a D major chord and sometimes thinking this way can be useful since getting all the alterations can be difficult or impossible.
3. G minor pentatonic will should carry you through the entire song pretty well.
4. Bb major pentatonic or Bb major scale would also work.
5. G harmonic minor works but you have to really time it correctly. You would have to analyze the chords and realize when you are playing Fs versus F#s
6. The second half seems out of tune. Sorry about this. I've never had MIDI play out of tune before.

videos.title: Meditative D Ionian Backing Track ‚Äî With Scale Chart for Guitar Improvisation
videos.description:
This makes for GREAT guitar practice. Close to the piano style of Eric Satie because of the minimalism and double notes. Chill and meditative music in D major key. The scale image is very intuitive and takes no music theory training; blue is relaxing, yellow is semi-dissonant, and red is uncomfortable dissonance. It's easy for many place to show a scale chart, it's rare for someone to actually explain what the meaning of the notes are. 

D Ionian is the same thing as D Major.

B minor also works since it is the relative minor of D Major (contains the same seven notes).

D E F# G A B C# D
                    B C# D E F# G A B


Blue = Home ~Root ~ Stable ~ "Pretty" ~ Tonic ~ Answers
Yellow = Semi-Stable ~ Semi-"Pretty" ~ Predominant ~ Incomplete 
Red = Unstable ~ "Ugly" ~ Dominant ~ Questions

Take the colors with a grain of salt. It is pretty accurate with this jam because it is pretty clearly in B minor and not modal. If the song is modal, these colors no longer apply. Also the colors only apply in the grand scheme of the entire song. So for example, a A major chord would turn A's from yellow to blue temporarily.

Blue = Home ~Root ~ Stable ~ "Pretty" ~ Tonic ~ Answers
Yellow = Semi-Stable ~ Semi-"Pretty" ~ Predominant ~ Incomplete 
Red = Unstable ~ "Ugly" ~ Dominant ~ Questions

Take these colors with a grain of salt. It is pretty accurate with this jam because it is pretty clearly in a minor and not modal. If the song is modal, these colors no longer apply. Also the colors only apply in the grand scheme of the entire song. So for example, a F major chord would turn F's from red to blue temporarily. 

Do you like the handwritten scale chart or do you think I should take the time to photoshop a more perfect, computerized grid?

videos.title: ‚ÄúEyes Open‚Äù ‚Äî Advanced Guitar Backing Track (Challenging Progressions)
videos.description:
This video shows very epic music along side sheet music scrolling. I decided to just show a leadsheet instead of a scale. I used MIDI pickups for it which is always fun. If a musician is able to play over top of this in the key of E Harmonic minor basically, then I'm sure they will have a fun time.

The key doesn't stray far from e minor and e harmonic minor. D/D#'s and F/F#'s are really the variable notes so watch out for them. 

This reminds me of jazz because of the complex harmonies but it sounds very little like vintage jazz.

videos.title: E Harmonic Minor Jazz Backing Track ‚Äî Smooth Groove + Scrolling Sheet Music
videos.description:
üéº Key: E minor
üéµ Style: Jazz / Smooth Groove
üé∏ Best for: Guitar, improvisation, solo practice, warm-ups, lessons, and backing track study
üìú Includes: Scrolling sheet music for easy visual reference while jamming

If you want more backing tracks, strange keys, jazz grooves, or classical guitar recordings, feel free to explore the playlists on my channel.

The hardest backing track I've uploaded yet. You can either be super theoretical about it or just use E natural minor, E minor pentatonic, E minor blues and E harmonic minor and then practice "squeaking" your way out of trouble. Basically, if you play a wrong note by accident, the right note is probably a half step away.

This jazz backing track in E minor combines a smooth, soulful groove with a scrolling sheet music display to help musicians practice improvisation, phrasing, and scale navigation. Whether you play guitar, piano, saxophone, or bass, this track gives you space to explore melodic ideas, chord tones, and expressive soloing techniques in a relaxed jazz setting.

videos.title: Autumn Leaves Backing Track Jazz üé∑ E minor with Chord Changes ( 120 BPM w/ swing )‚ô© ‚ô™ ‚ô´ ‚ô¨
videos.description:
Funk Jazzy Autumn Leaves Backing Music Track in E minor. Ideal for musicians that want to practicing improvising solos. This is an ideal beginner friendly jazz song to learn from. Features guitar, acoustic double bass, and drums, but the melody is left out intentionally. 
Composed by: Joseph Kosma

This may not be Autumn leaves exactly but it is very close and I think it works on the same changes. Measure 16 is a GMaj7 in the original not a CMaj7. Also the lengths of some chords are not the same as the real book original. 

There is guitar, bass and drums in this backing track but I think there is still room for a lead instrument or playing the original melody to Autumn Leaves. If you don't know what to play, check out my guitar PDFs below at sheet music direct, I have fantastic PDFs that explain chords and scales. This song is a little bit more on the difficult side because there is basically only chord names to go off of, but that is in the jazz ethos anyways, which is why I was okay uploading a bare-bones version.

videos.title: G Harmonic minor Backing Track ‚Äì OPEN D MAJOR TUNING ‚Äì¬†Indian Raga with Guitar Scale Chart in
videos.description:
****IMPORTANT****Tune your guitar to DADGAD...otherwise this scale chart won't work. If you don't want to retune the letter names are D Eb F# G A Bb D.   (Perhaps a C# could work) G harmonic minor is a much more common way to think about this scale.

This video features a very tribal, exotic, gypsy, and ancient sounding backing track. It sounds like it is music from India or the Middle East. It is a very difficult backing track because it is an unusual scale. It is hard to name that scale, I often call it harmonic major, Jewish, or a mode of harmonic minor, in this case, G harmonic minor. It's all fancy terminology, but basically you need a two fret skip to give that desert music feeling.

Try doing quick Slides/glissandos on these notes. Also I recommend some extreme bending on the notes D, F# and A. You will sound even more like a Sitar!

This one is hard to jam too, the triplets were getting the better of me, they are hard to predict for sure. The rhythm is quite complex and unintuitive and it is a rare scale. But try your best and I'm sure you'll come up with cool ideas regardless so at least you can see where I'm coming from when I made this. Thanks for watching!

1. I looped it three times
2. There are triplets before major down beats 
3. The blue note on the scale chart is the most resolute note, where D# tends to be in the ugliest
4. This scale only has 5 notes, which is part of the reason why it sounds so ancient sounding
5. Tuning: DADGAD. That way every open string is a note of the scale allowing for drone notes and mysterious sounding voicings of chords and melodic freedom since you can pretty just use your index finger on one string at a time and have opens on the 5 other strings. 

Letters:              D Eb F# G A Bb D
Scale degrees: 1 b2 3 4 5 b6 8
Solfedge: Do Ra Mi Fa So Ley Do

videos.title: Metal in the style of Mozart
videos.description:
Metal Mozart 

It's metal music based off a melody from the first Act of:
Theme from The Magic Flute K 620 (Die Zauberfl√∂te)
or it's based off the third variation in:
Introduction and Variations on a Theme by Mozart, Op. 9 by Fernando Sor

If your looking for a historically accurate version you might want to look elsewhere. I plan on uploading a more historically accurate version because I do know Fernando Sor's Introduction and Variations on a Theme by Mozart, Op. 9 on classical guitar. But I stumbled across this and well, I think metal guitarist go crazy for something cool that's not in D minor for once. Plus it does kind of show that classical music isn't always flowery and nice, don't let the clean timbre fool you, there's a lot filthy intervals and keys in Mozart that are also used in Metal.

videos.title: Sarabande from Bach Cello Suite 2 ~ Arranged for Guitar ~ BWV 1008
videos.description:
Sarabande from Bach Cello Suite 2 (Classical Guitar) ~ BWV 1008

Johann Sebastian Bach[a] (31 March [O.S. 21 March] 1685 ‚Äì 28 July 1750) was a German composer and musician of the Baroque period. He enriched established German styles through his skill in counterpoint, harmonic and motivic organization, and the adaptation of rhythms, forms, and textures from abroad, particularly from Italy and France. Bach's compositions include the Brandenburg Concertos, the Goldberg Variations, the Mass in B minor, two Passions, and over three hundred cantatas of which around two hundred survive.[1] His music is revered for its technical command, artistic beauty, and intellectual depth.

Bach's abilities as an organist were highly respected during his lifetime, although he was not widely recognized as a great composer until a revival of interest and performances of his music in the first half of the 19th century. He is now generally regarded as one of the greatest composers of all time.

videos.title: The History of Guitar Tablature (Luis Milan Pavane 3)
videos.description:
Skip to the music if you'd like: 8:47

This video is about the history of guitar tablature and it also features a recording of mine along with a representation of what the actual tablature would of looked like back then.

My original idea was to just upload the recording but I thought it would be interesting to give some historical context and to have the music "scroll" like in a music software program. I hope you enjoy it!

Some things I forgot to mention:
1.  I use a capo to mimic the tuning a vihuela more accurately (it was smaller than a modern guitar). So the numbers from the tablature are actually +3 on every number or one can think the open string with the capo is then "0". 
2. I don't always follow the frets exactly, I have my own arrangement.
3. I do melismatic (ornamental notes) cadences that aren't in the original tablature
4. Luis Milan was in the Spanish Valencia court. 
5. Luis Milan was the first composer to have tempo indications like "allegro", "largo", etc...

Please subscribe, share, like, etc...Thanks!

videos.title: Luis Milan - Pavane 2 from El Maestro (2015)
videos.description:
Luys de Milan - Pavana Pavane II from " Libro de musica de vihuela de mano, intitulado El Maestro ( Music book of hand vihuela, entitled The Master ). ( 1536 ) " seis Fantasias en forma de Pavana 
Spanish Early / Renaissance Music 

Luis de Mil√°n (also known as Llu√≠s del Mil√† or Luys Mil√°n) (c. 1500 ‚Äì c. 1561) was a Spanish Renaissance composer, vihuelist (a forerunner to the baroque guitar), and writer on music. He was the first composer in history to publish music for the vihuela de mano, an instrument employed primarily in the Iberian peninsula and some of the Italian states during the 15th and 16th centuries, and he was also one of the first musicians to specify verbal tempo indications in his music.

This music is for the vihuela but it is similar to lute music. It also sounds like choral part-writing with independent soprano, alto, tenor and bass voices but for the guitar. 

I get a little better every time I record I think. I thought this turned out pretty good. Stay tuned!

videos.title: Pachelbel‚Äôs Canon in D ‚Äî Classical Guitar Arrangement
videos.description:
Pachelbel‚Äôs Canon in D ‚Äî Unique Classical Guitar Arrangement
Johann Pachelbel was a **German Baroque composer and organist**, best known today for his contributions to keyboard music and Protestant church repertoire. He lived during the same general era as composers like Buxtehude and early J.S. Bach, and he was a highly respected musician in his lifetime.

### **Key facts about Pachelbel:**

* Born in Nuremberg, Germany.
* Studied at the University of Altdorf and later in Regensburg.
* Worked as a court and church organist in Vienna, Eisenach, Erfurt, Stuttgart, and other cities.
* Served as a teacher and influenced future generations ‚Äî notably **Johann Ambrosius Bach**, father of **Johann Sebastian Bach**.
* Wrote **chorale preludes, fugues, toccatas, chamber music**, and sacred works.
* Known for his clear counterpoint, expressive but orderly voice-leading, and technically approachable keyboard writing.

Pachelbel‚Äôs music bridges the early and high Baroque, combining Italian clarity with German contrapuntal tradition.

---

# üéµ **Canon in D ‚Äî Historical Information**

**Canon in D Major**, often simply called *Canon in D*, is Pachelbel‚Äôs most famous composition ‚Äî though ironically it was not widely known for nearly 300 years after it was written.

### **Date and Context**

* Composed around **1680‚Äì1700**.
* Originally written for **three violins and basso continuo** (not solo guitar).
* The piece is part of a small chamber collection titled the *Canon and Gigue in D major*.

The **Canon** is followed immediately by a lively **Gigue**, though the Canon is the part that became world-famous.

---

# ‚≠ê **Musical Structure**

Canon in D is built on:

* A **ground bass** ‚Äî a repeating 8-note bass-line pattern.
* A **canon** ‚Äî each violin imitates the previous one, entering in sequence.
* Simple harmonic progression that repeats throughout, creating a sense of inevitability and calm.

This makes it a **perfect loop**, which is partly why it became so iconic.

---

# üìà **Pop Culture and Rediscovery**

Canon in D was **not well known** until the **20th century**, when:

* Musicologists rediscovered the manuscript in the early 1900s.
* Classical guitarists, violinists, and arrangers began performing it.
* It became extremely popular in the 1960s‚Äì1990s due to:

  * Wedding ceremonies
  * Film scores (e.g., *Ordinary People*)
  * New Age and classical crossover recordings
  * Pop songs borrowing its chord progression (e.g., ‚ÄúBasket Case,‚Äù ‚ÄúGraduation (Friends Forever),‚Äù ‚ÄúGo West,‚Äù ‚ÄúMemories‚Äù)

Today it is one of the **most recognized pieces in Western classical music**, despite being almost unknown during Pachelbel‚Äôs lifetime.

---

# üé∏ **Why It Works on Guitar**

Although originally for violins, the piece adapts beautifully to guitar because:

* The repeating bass progression fits classical guitar arpeggios
* Harmonies are diatonic and resonant
* The texture naturally supports fingerstyle interpretation
* It allows expressive control over voices and ornaments

It‚Äôs a favorite for:

* Weddings
* Recitals
* YouTube performances
* Classical guitar students learning counterpoint

---

If you want, I can now write:

* a **YouTube-ready description** combining this info,
* a **shorter version** for your video summary,
* or a **more detailed musicological analysis**.

videos.title: Doom D Mongolian Minor Metal Backing Track 74 BPM with Scale Chart
videos.description:
WARNING: Violence/Gore in this video

D Mongolian Minor Creepy Scary In-the-zone Backing Track 74 BPM with Scale Chart (really Eb minor...tune down 1/2!?). 7 minutes of white knuckle metal soloing!

This is a silly video that I came up with, it's not the greatest but I decided to upload anyways. Sorry the audio and rhythmic clarity isn't the greatest and it is a difficult one to solo to but here it is anyways.

This gameplay is from a video game game is called Doom II: Hell on Earth. Just seemed super appropriate for the mood of the backing track. It's a PC game produced by id Software in 1994. I used this website to play it on my mac (because it is a DOS game):

http://www.chocolate-doom.org/wiki/index.php/Downloads

1. Tune  down a 1/2 step in 440 hertz and think "fake key of d Mongolian minor". I think this would be practically impossible in standard tuning.
2. I showed a synthetic pitch collection because just regular d minor might sound a bit awkward and weak, so perhaps use d minor as a guide but mess up every now and then... The scale is basically a hideous version of d minor that doesn't even have a name yet but it is pretty similar to Mongolian minor or the half-whole scale but with more chromaticism around the 3rd and 4th scale degrees: D Eb F F# G Ab A Bb C# D...so no Es, Bs or Cs is my recommendation, though I'm not saying those notes are impossible to work into it. Here is scale's jpg: 

http://www.guitarmasterclass.net/images/scales/gmcscale_d_synthetic_1_e10111111001R10_b001R101111110_g1111001R10111_dR10111111001R_a11001R1011111_e60111111001R10.jpg

3. There are a ton of polymeters in this backing track. My suggestion would be to aim for big down beats and be confident in what rhythm you choose because whether this track is in 3/4 or 4/4  is a ambiguous.
4. The chord Progression I'm using is this: i (dm) bII (Eb Neapolitan) V/V (G#5) Vb9 (A  (b9) i (dm) or basically 0 1 6 7 in drop D power chords.

videos.title: Ear Training ‚Äì Greek Modes with Visual Representations
videos.description:
Demo of Ear Master software program and I give advice on how to have better ears in music; better relative pitch.

Tips & Tricks:
1. Take the time to know what notes separate the scales by comparing them to Major or Minor (Ex. Phrygian is a minor scale with a b2). There is a chart to write down below. I would take the time to do so if you are unsure of the notes and interval content.
2. Know the Circle of Fifths/Major and Minors really well first before tackling modes. Some of my tips assume that you already know how Major and Minor keys work.
3. The smiley face/sad face is not right and wrong for the dictations. I could see where there could be some confusion here. I just thought the two pictures are perfectly representative of major and minor because they are the very stock and bread and butter flavors of happiness and sadness in music. Perhaps I'll use the greek happy and sad faces next time.
4. Can't remember the intervals that compose the modes? Remember, modes are slightly different than "scales", though the terms are somewhat interchangeable. A Mode means it is just a rearrangement of the "starting point" or "root note" of the original seven note scale. One can create as many modes as there are notes in the scale. There are 7 notes in C Major (A. K. A. Ionian), therefore there a seven modes of C Major when the original scale is included. 7 possible rearrangements for 7 notes (But 1. One must go in the musical alphabetical order 2.There is no H in the musical alphabet). The Chart includes what picture I use to represent it and * are placed by scale degrees you should be listening for because they really distinguish the scale/mode:

1. (Happy Face) C Ionian is C to C with no accidentals: C D E F G A B C
or Numbers: 1 2 3 4 5  6 7  8
or Solfeggio: Do Re Mi Fa Sol La Ti Do

2. (Greek Harp Player) D Dorian is D to D with no accidentals: D E F G A B C D
or Numbers: 1 2 b3 4 5  6* b7  8
or Solfeggio: Do Re Mey Fa Sol La* Tey Do 

3. (Mexican Guy with Classical Guitar) E Phrygian is E to E with no accidentals: E F G A B C D E
or Numbers: 1 b2* b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
or Solfeggio: Do Ra* Mey Fa Sol Ley Tey Do 

4. (Link / Wood Elf) F Lydian is F to F with no accidentals: F G A B C D E F 
or Numbers: 1  2  3 #4*  5  6 7  8
or Solfeggio: Do Re Mi FI* Sol La Ti Do 

5. (Honkey Tonk) G Mixolydian is G to G with no accidentals: G A B C D E F G
or Numbers: 1 2 3 4 5  6 b7*  8
or Solfedge: Do Re Mi Fa Sol La Tey* Do 

6. (Sad Face) A Aeolian is A to A with no accidentals: A B C D E F G A
or Numbers: 1 2 b3 4 5  b6 b7  8
or Solfedge: Do Re Mey Fa Sol Ley Tey Do 

7. (Devil with electric guitar) B Locrian is B to B with no accidentals: B C D E F G A B
or Numbers: 1 b2 b3 4 b5* b6 b7  8
or Solfedge: Do Ra Mey Fa Sey* Ley Tey Do 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
5. The letters are useful because the X to X with no accidentals trick is easy to remember. And from there you can figure out the intervals and everything else one needs to know. It's basically doing all your theory work in C Major first because it's the clearest of all the keys to think it because it doesn't need a key signature, accidentals, or black keys on the piano. Then, after much pratice, you can start to transfer things over to weird keys like Gb Major for instance, with the number system.
6. The numbers (They are derived from the distance between the letters) are useful because the key is vague, allowing one to figure out the other 77 (7 x 11.....Number of modes possible x 12 separate pitches in the western music system, -1 because we've already done "C"...so 7 x11 remaining) Greek modes that aren't listed here. Sounds like a lot but remember; it's useful to think in dozens if your a musician because there's 12 notes in the western music system. If you know one Phrygian, maybe you really know 11 more theoretically? Take a look (Notice how the letters change but the number formula for Phrygian doesn't):

1. E Phrygian: E F G A B C D E ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
2. F Phrygian: F Ab Bb C Db Eb F ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
3. F# Phrygian: F# G A B C# D E F# ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
4. G Phrygian: G Ab Bb C D Eb F G ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
5. Ab Phrygian: Ab Bbb Cb Db Eb Fb Gb Ab ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
6. A Phrygian: A Bb C D E F G A ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
7. Bb Phrygian: Bb Cb Db Eb F Gb Ab Bb ~~~1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
8. B Phrygian: B C D E F# G A B ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
9. C Phrygian: C Db Eb F G Ab Bb C ~~~1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
10. C# Phrygian: C# D E F# G# A B C# ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8 
11. D Phrygian: D Eb F G A Bb C D ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
12. Eb Phrygian: Eb Fb Gb Ab Bb Cb Db Eb ~~~ 1 b2 b3 4 5 b6 b7 8
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
7. All the modes have only one note difference to either the major or minor scale except for locrian. 
8. Locian is a major scale with everything flatted a half step except for the 4th scale degree.
Ear Training Lesson 5 Greek Modes with Visual Representations

videos.title: T√°rrega ‚Äî Gran Vals (The Great Waltz) ‚Äì Classical Guitar
videos.description:
A very happy waltz for guitar that reminds me of European beer gardens and pubs. This is the happiest song I play I think, and it is slightly goofy sounding, yet also virtuosic. 

This video features a classical guitar performance of Francisco T√°rrega‚Äôs music, highlighting the expressive Romantic style and lyrical phrasing that make his works central to the guitar repertoire. T√°rrega‚Äôs writing blends elegant melodies, warm harmonies, and idiomatic fingerstyle technique, creating pieces that are both accessible to students and deeply rewarding for advanced players.

Francisco T√°rrega (1852‚Äì1909) was a Spanish composer, guitarist, and teacher often regarded as the father of modern classical guitar technique. Born in Villarreal, Spain, he studied both guitar and piano from an early age‚Äîan unusual combination that shaped his harmonic language and the way he voiced chords on the guitar. After conservatory training in Madrid, T√°rrega became one of Europe‚Äôs most respected guitar virtuosos, performing widely and teaching the next generation of influential players.

T√°rrega‚Äôs music is known for:

Romantic lyricism

Spanish folk influence

Beautiful melodic lines

Clean, idiomatic guitar writing

Expressive phrasing and warm tone colors

His most famous works include ‚ÄúRecuerdos de la Alhambra,‚Äù ‚ÄúL√°grima,‚Äù ‚ÄúAdelita,‚Äù ‚ÄúCapricho √Årabe,‚Äù and numerous preludes, waltzes, mazurkas, and √©tudes. These pieces helped elevate the guitar from a parlor instrument to a respected concert instrument and laid the technical foundations that later influenced Miguel Llobet, Emilio Pujol, Andr√©s Segovia, and the entire modern classical guitar tradition.

T√°rrega‚Äôs music remains essential in recitals, teaching studios, and classical guitar recordings, cherished for its emotional depth and timeless beauty.

Gran Vals (The Great Waltz) - Francisco T√°rrega
A. K. A. Nokia Ring Tone
Performed by Brian Streckfus at Peabody Conservatory. Senior Recital at Cohen Davison Theatre. 

Francisco de As√≠s T√°rrega y Eixea (21 November 1852 ‚Äì 15 December 1909) was a Spanish composer and classical guitarist of the Romantic period.

videos.title: Marieta (Mazurka) ~ Francisco Tarrega
videos.description:
Marieta/Mazurka by Francisco Tarr√©ga, performed by Brian Streckfus. 

(2015) Peabody Conservatory, Cohen Davison Family Theatre

This video features Francisco T√°rrega‚Äôs *Marieta (Mazurka)* for classical guitar ‚Äî a lyrical Romantic miniature known for its elegant melody, expressive phrasing, and characteristic Spanish charm. This performance highlights the piece‚Äôs flowing dance rhythm and warm guitar textures.

Francisco T√°rrega (1852‚Äì1909) is often considered the father of modern classical guitar technique. A Spanish composer and virtuoso, he helped elevate the guitar to a respected concert instrument, writing expressive works such as *L√°grima*, *Adelita*, *Capricho √Årabe*, and *Recuerdos de la Alhambra*. His music blends Romantic lyricism, Spanish folk color, and beautifully idiomatic guitar writing ‚Äî qualities that make *Marieta* one of his most beloved mazurkas.

If you‚Äôre learning this piece, listening for phrasing, or exploring Romantic-era guitar repertoire, this recording offers a clear and musical interpretation of T√°rrega‚Äôs style.

üé∏ **Composer:** Francisco T√°rrega
üé∂ **Piece:** *Marieta (Mazurka)*
üéº **Style:** Romantic / Spanish Classical Guitar
üìú **Level:** Intermediate‚ÄìAdvanced

A **mazurka** is a **lively Polish dance** in **triple meter (3/4 time)**, traditionally featuring a strong accent **not** on the downbeat, but on the **2nd or 3rd beat** of the measure.

Here are the core traits:

### ‚≠ê **Mazurka ‚Äî Definition**

A **mazurka** is a **Polish folk dance and musical form** in **3/4 time**, characterized by:

* **Accents on beat 2 or 3** (unlike the waltz, which accents beat 1)
* A **moderate to fast tempo**
* A rhythmic ‚Äúlift‚Äù or skipping feel
* Often a dotted or syncopated rhythm
* A distinctive **folk, rustic, or dance-like character**

### üéº **Musical Characteristics**

* Triple meter (3/4)
* Emphasis on **off-beats**
* Often uses **dotted rhythms**
* Can sound playful, elegant, or rustic
* Sometimes features a repeating bass pattern or ‚Äúoom-cha-cha‚Äù feel but with shifted accents

### üéπ **Where It Appears**

* **Polish folk tradition**
* **Chopin‚Äôs Mazurkas** (the most famous classical examples)
* Late Romantic and guitar miniatures (including T√°rrega)
* Dance suites, salon music, and nationalistic classical works

T√°rrega adapted the mazurka style into intimate, lyrical guitar pieces. His mazurkas (like *Marieta* and *Adelita*) combine:

* Romantic harmony
* Spanish guitar flavor
* Light dance rhythms
* Clear melodic lines

videos.title: Mazurka (Choro) ~ Villa Lobos from Suite Populaire Br√©silienne
videos.description:
"Mazurka" from Suite Br√©silienne performed by Brian Streckfus on classical guitar. Peabody Conservatory at Cohen-Davison Family Theatre. This recording features Heitor Villa-Lobos‚Äô ‚ÄúMazurka (Choro)‚Äù from the Suite Populaire Br√©silienne, showcasing his unique blend of Brazilian folk rhythm and early 20th-century classical guitar writing. The piece‚Äôs lyrical lines, choro-inspired syncopation, and expressive harmonies reveal Villa-Lobos‚Äô signature style and his deep influence on modern guitar repertoire.

üéµ Mazurka ‚Äî Definition

A mazurka is a Polish dance and musical form in triple meter (3/4 time), distinguished by:

Accents on beat 2 or 3 (unlike the waltz, which accents beat 1)

A moderate to fast tempo

Characteristic dotted rhythms and off-beat accents

A rustic, folk-dance feel with a slight ‚Äúlift‚Äù

Mazurkas became widely known through Chopin, and later entered guitar repertoire through composers like T√°rrega, who adapted their rhythmic charm into expressive salon pieces.

üé∂ Choro ‚Äî Definition

A choro (pronounced SHOH-roh) is a Brazilian instrumental genre that emerged in the late 19th century. It is known for:

Lively, virtuosic melodies

Syncopated rhythms

A blend of European harmony, African rhythm, and Brazilian dance styles

Small ensemble textures (guitar, cavaquinho, flute, clarinet, pandeiro)

Even though ‚Äúchoro‚Äù literally means ‚Äúcry‚Äù, the music is usually joyful, fast, and playful, similar to ragtime or early jazz in its improvisatory spirit.
Villa-Lobos incorporated choro elements into classical compositions, blending folk energy with modern harmonic language.

Heitor Villa-Lobos (Portuguese: [ejÀåto Å Àåvil…ê Ààlobus]; March 5, 1887 ‚Äì November 17, 1959) was a Brazilian composer, described as "the single most significant creative figure in 20th-century Brazilian art music".[1] Villa-Lobos has become the best-known and most significant Latin American composer to date.[2] A prolific composer, he wrote numerous orchestral, chamber, instrumental and vocal works, totaling over 2000 works by his death in 1959. His music was influenced by both Brazilian folk music and by stylistic elements from the European classical tradition, as exemplified by his Bachianas Brasileiras (Brazilian Bachian-pieces). His preludes for guitar, written in 1940, are important works in the guitar repertory, and were inspired by Andr√©s Segovia.

A Maria Teresa Teran

Johann Sebastian Bach[1] (31 March [O.S. 21 March] 1685 ‚Äì 28 July 1750) was a German composer and musician of the Baroque period. He enriched established German styles through his skill in counterpoint, harmonic and motivic organisation, and the adaptation of rhythms, forms, and textures from abroad, particularly from Italy and France. His music is revered for its technical command, artistic beauty, and intellectual depth.

videos.title: Narv√°ez ‚Äî Gu√°rdame las Vacas (Classical Guitar)
videos.description:
This recording features Gu√°rdame las Vacas by Luis de Narv√°ez, one of the most iconic works in the Spanish Renaissance vihuela tradition. This performance highlights the piece‚Äôs elegant variations, rhythmic clarity, and expressive counterpoint as adapted for classical guitar.

This video presents Gu√°rdame las Vacas by Luis de Narv√°ez, a foundational piece of the Spanish Renaissance vihuela repertoire. Known for its elegant theme and set of variations, the work demonstrates the sophisticated yet accessible style that made Narv√°ez one of the most influential composers of early plucked-string music. This performance offers a clear and expressive interpretation of the piece on classical guitar.

Luis de Narv√°ez (fl. 1526‚Äì1549) was a leading Spanish vihuelist and composer, best known for his groundbreaking publication Los seys libros del Delph√≠n (1538), the earliest printed book of vihuela music. His compositions showcase refined counterpoint, expressive variation technique, and a seamless blend of Spanish musical aesthetics with Renaissance polyphony. Narv√°ez helped shape the early evolution of guitar-family instruments, and works like Gu√°rdame las Vacas, La Canci√≥n del Emperador, and his diferencias (variations) remain essential repertoire for both vihuelists and classical guitarists today.

üé∏ Piece: Gu√°rdame las Vacas
üéº Composer: Luis de Narv√°ez
üìÄ Era: Spanish Renaissance (16th Century)
üéµ Style: Vihuela / Early Music / Classical Guitar
üìö Difficulty: Intermediate‚ÄìAdvanced

If you enjoy early music, vihuela repertoire, or historical guitar arrangements, this piece is a perfect example of Renaissance variation technique and beautifully idiomatic plucked-string writing.

Luis de Narv√°ez (fl. 1526‚Äì49) was a Spanish composer and vihuelist. Highly regarded during his lifetime, Narv√°ez is known today for Los seys libros del delph√≠n, a collection of polyphonic music for the vihuela which includes the earliest known variation sets. He is also notable for being the earliest composer for vihuela to adapt the contemporary Italian style of lute music.

Luis de Narvaez Guardame Las Vacas performed by Brian Streckfus at Cohen Davison Family Theatre at the Peabody Conservatory. Recorded March 29th, 2015.

I'm in vihuela tuning for this video, Capo on fret 3:
E
B
F#
D
A
E

videos.title: Mil√°n ‚Äî Pavane No. 5 (El Maestro, 1536) ‚Äî Classical Guitar
videos.description:
This video features Luis Mil√°n‚Äôs Pavane No. 5 from El Maestro (1536), beautifully arranged and performed on classical guitar. This Renaissance pavane highlights Mil√°n‚Äôs elegant style, expressive counterpoint, and the intimate sound world of early Spanish vihuela music.

Luis Mil√°n (c. 1500‚Äì1561) was a Spanish Renaissance composer, vihuelist, poet, and court musician best known for his groundbreaking 1536 publication El Maestro, the first printed book of vihuela music in history. Pavane No. 5 is one of the lyrical instrumental dances from this collection, written in Mil√°n‚Äôs distinctive blend of elegant chordal writing and expressive melodic lines.

El Maestro contains pavanes, fantas√≠as, and songs that showcase the vihuela‚Äôs noble, intimate tone ‚Äî the direct ancestor of the modern classical guitar. Mil√°n wrote his music with remarkable clarity and included some of the earliest performance instructions in print. Pavane No. 5 is especially beloved for its dignified phrasing, Renaissance harmonic color, and smooth voice-leading, making it a favorite among classical guitarists exploring early music repertoire.

üé∏ Composer: Luis Mil√°n
üìú Work: Pavane No. 5 (from El Maestro, 1536)
üéº Style: Renaissance / Vihuela / Early Music
üéµ Instrument: Classical Guitar

If you enjoy early music, vihuela repertoire, or Renaissance lute/guitar arrangements, this is a wonderful piece to explore.

Luys de Milan - Pavana Pavane five from " Libro de musica de vihuela de mano, intitulado El Maestro " ( Music book of hand vihuela, entitled The Master ). ( 1536 ) " seis Fantasias en forma de Pavana "

Spanish Early / Renaissance Music

Performed by: Brian Streckfus
Recording #2: 2015 Recital Performance at Peabody Conservatory in Cohen Davison Family Theatre

Luis de Mil√°n (also known as Llu√≠s del Mil√† or Luys Mil√°n) (c. 1500 ‚Äì c. 1561) was a Spanish Renaissance composer, vihuelist (a forerunner to the baroque guitar), and writer on music. He was the first composer in history to publish music for the vihuela de mano, an instrument employed primarily in the Iberian peninsula and some of the Italian states during the 15th and 16th centuries, and he was also one of the first musicians to specify verbal tempo indications in his music.

videos.title: Luis Mil√°n: Pavane I from El Maestro ‚Äî Guitar Recording
videos.description:
Luis de Mil√°n‚Äôs Pavane No. 1 from El Maestro (1536) is a cornerstone of the Spanish Renaissance vihuela tradition, known for its graceful melody and noble dance character. This classical guitar performance offers a clear, expressive interpretation that highlights Mil√°n‚Äôs beautiful writing and historical style.

This video features Luis de Mil√°n‚Äôs Pavane No. 1 from El Maestro (1536), one of the foundational works of the Spanish Renaissance vihuela repertoire. Mil√°n was a Valencian composer, poet, and vihuelist whose collection El Maestro is the earliest known printed book for the vihuela, offering detailed instructions for technique, ornamentation, and expressive performance. Pavane No. 1 showcases Mil√°n‚Äôs elegant counterpoint, flowing melodic lines, and gentle dance character, making it a favorite among classical guitarists today.

This performance presents a clean and expressive interpretation adapted for modern classical guitar, preserving the modal color and courtly style of the original vihuela setting. If you enjoy Renaissance music, early plucked-string repertoire, or classical guitar interpretations of historic works, this recording provides a clear and musical presentation of one of Mil√°n‚Äôs most enduring pieces.

Luys de Milan - Pavana Pavane one from "Libro de musica de vihuela de mano, intitulado El Maestro" (Music book of hand vihuela, entitled The Master). (1536) "seis Fantasias en forma de Pavana"

Spanish Early / Renaissance Music 

Performed by: Brian Streckfus
Recording #2: 2015 Recital Performance at Peabody Conservatory in Cohen Davison Family Theatre

Luis de Mil√°n (also known as Llu√≠s del Mil√† or Luys Mil√°n) (c. 1500 ‚Äì c. 1561) was a Spanish Renaissance composer, vihuelist (a forerunner to the baroque guitar), and writer on music. He was the first composer in history to publish music for the vihuela de mano, an instrument employed primarily in the Iberian peninsula and some of the Italian states during the 15th and 16th centuries, and he was also one of the first musicians to specify verbal tempo indications in his music.

videos.title: A Minor Backing Track with Guitar Scale Chart 120 BPM
videos.description:
IMPORTANT: Please Read Description for Tips!

The Chord Progression is mostly Am G F Em. 

1. Make sure you tune to A=440
2. The blue notes are root notes and usually the most resolute and often used to end musical sentences. 
3. Use A minor pentantonic to build chords if you are building chords. This makes it a bit easier to jam chords without knowing my exact chord progression.
4. The chord progression is often am ~ GM ~ FM ~ em. i VII VI v
5. If A Minor ever gets to easy, you can tune your guitar down steps to try different keys. Tune a whole step down to work on G minor shapes for example. So this backing track could actually be used to study a few keys and modes not just A minor. 
6. Randomizing it a bit can sound better than doing scale runs all the time, that can sound a bit boring. Jump and skip around to random notes and you'll sound a bit more jazzy.
7. The ending is a half cadence, so end on something other than the note "A" most likely.

A Minor Aeolian Backing Jam Track with Guitar Scale Chart 120 BPM II by Brian Streckfus

Ambient, Soft Rock, Indie, Electronic, Experimental
Learn how to solo, improvise, free-style, compose better in a very hands on and fun way! It's what real guitar hero looks like if you will, haha, and it's what I picture in my head when I'm improvising.

NAME: PICTURE - VISUAL REPRESENTATION 
(TIPS)
SCALE DEGREE #'s
SOLFEGGIO
EXAME OF SCALE STARTING FROM THE NOTE "C" 

Major (ionian mode): Smiley Face
(A bland happy, sounds like a singing exercise)
1    2    3   4   5   6   7  8
Do Re Mi Fa So La Ti Do
C D E F G A B C

Minor(aeolian mode): Sad Face
(A Bland sad, can sound like a pirate music at times)
1    2    b3    4   5   b6  b7   8
Do Re Mey Fa So ley tey Do
C D Eb F G Ab Bb C

Phrygian: Mexican Village
(A sad scale with an Iberian Peninsula Vibe (b2), flamenco type guitar music.)
1   b2    b3    4    5   b6   b7   8
Do Ra  Mey Fa Sol Ley Tey Do
C Db Eb F G Ab Bb C

Lydian: Link from Zelda
(Extra Happy, Wood-elf scale, Major but with #4)
1    2    3   #4   5      6   7   8
Do Re Mi  Fi   Sol   La Ti  Do
C D E F# G A B C

Whole-Tone: La-La Land
(Time warp scale, A scale without direction or meaning)
1   2   3  #4  #5  #6  8
Do Re Mi Fi Si Li Do
C D E F# G# A# C

Harmonic Minor: Arabian Knights
(A sad scale with a lot of edge, used to build stereotypical chord progressions)
1   2   b3   4   5  b6   7   8
Do Re Mey Fa Sol ley Ti Do
C D Eb F G Ab B C

Chromatic: Cat walking on piano
(Nothing but half steps, one note after another, twelve notes, ugly or wrong sounding)
1  b2   2   b3    3    4   b5    5    b6   6   b7    7   8
Do Ra Re Mey Mi Fa Fi Sol Ley La Tey Ti Do
C Db D Eb E F Gb G Ab A Bb B C

Blues: Robert Johnson Blues
(Self Explanatory, minor pentatonic but with a b5 that adds a lot of edge)
1  b3 4 b5 5 b7 8
Do Mey Fa Fi Sol Tey Do
C Eb F Gb G Bb C

Major Pentatonic: Asian girl with pink Cherry Blossoms
(Happy female oriental sounding, five different notes, hence "penta", big leaps, wind-chime scale)
1 3 4 5 6 8
Do Mi Fa So La Do
C E F G A C

Minor Pentatonic: Eric Clapton
(Sad Oriental scale. Used in guitar riffs A LOT! Five different notes, hence "penta", big leaps)
1 b3 4 5 b7 8
Do Mey Fa So Tey Do
C Eb F G Bb C

Jewish: Star of David Flag
1 b2 3 4 5 b6 b7 8
Do Ra Mi Fa So Ley Tey Do
C Db E F G Ab Bb C

Non-Retrogradable Indian Raga - Raga Zilaf (Asavari Thaat): Indian God Saraswati
(Five notes, very meditative, can't be retrograded)
1 3 4 5 b6 8
Do Mi Fa So Ley Do
C E F G Ab C 

Mongolian/Persian Minor - Mongol
(Lot's of edge, double A2+ between b2-3 and b6-7) 
1 b2 3 4 5 b6 7 8
Do Ra Mi Fa So Ley Ti Do
C Db E F G Ab B C

Ancient Japanse - Japanese monk drawing
(A. K. A. The "In Scale" or the "Sakura pentatonic scale", sounds oriental, five notes, much darker than the other oriental scales, Male Dragon Scale)
1 b2 4 5 b6 8
Do Ra Fa Sol Ley Do
C Db F G Ab C

Diminished Scale (1-1/2) - Lucifer with metal guitar
(A. K. A. the Stravinsky scale used in the "Rite of Spring". A symmetrical scale, used for improvising over diminished chords, Used in metal a lot, invert the half and whole steps and you wind up with the other diminished scale.)
1 2 b3 4 b5 b6 6 7 8
Do Re Mey Fa Sey Ley La Ti Do
C Db Eb F Gb Ab A B C

Melodic Minor - Lute Guy
(A less sad minor scale, sounds like early music, listen to Greensleeves if your having trouble with this one, it has: So Do... Re Mey...........but then La Ti Do for the final cadence.)
1 2 b3 4 5 6 7 8
Do Re Mey Fa So La Ti Do
C D Eb F G A B C

Dorian - No Picture, Couldn't think of one really, Help?? Maybe I could of done a Greek Picture
(A Greek Mode, A jazzy jam scale, A less sad minor, a minor scale with just a regular 6)
1 2 b3 4 5 6 b7 8
Do Re Mey Fa So La Tey Do
C D Eb F G A Bb C

Mixolydian: Honkey Tonk Piano
(Honkey Tonk Piano because a dominant 7th chord is embedded inside this scale and so you use this scale to improvise over dominant 7th chords, major but with a b7)
1 2 3 4 5 6 b7 8
Do Re Mi Fa So La Tey Do
C D E F G A Bb C

videos.title: Couperin ‚Äì La Dangereuse (Classical Guitar Duo Arrangement)
videos.description:
This video features a classical guitar duo arrangement of Fran√ßois Couperin‚Äôs La Dangereuse, a refined Baroque dance piece known for its elegant ornamentation and expressive charm. This performance highlights Couperin‚Äôs distinctive French Baroque style, adapted beautifully for two guitars with clear phrasing and vibrant tonal color.

Fran√ßois Couperin (1668‚Äì1733), known as ‚ÄúCouperin le Grand,‚Äù was one of the greatest French Baroque composers, celebrated for his refined harpsichord works and his mastery of nuanced ornamentation. La Dangereuse comes from his collections of keyboard pieces that blend courtly grace, expressive lyricism, and delicate rhythmic subtlety‚Äîtraits that translate beautifully to the classical guitar.

Couperin‚Äôs music is known for its poetic titles, graceful melodic lines, and intricate ornaments (agr√©ments) that define French Baroque style. This classical guitar duo arrangement of La Dangereuse brings out the interplay between voices, highlighting both the intimate and dance-like qualities of the original harpsichord composition. If you enjoy Baroque music, historical repertoire, or chamber guitar textures, this recording offers a warm and expressive interpretation of a timeless miniature.

videos.title: Couperin ‚Äì Les Vieux Seigneurs ‚ÄúThe Old Lords‚Äù | Classical Guitar Duo Arrangement
videos.description:
This video features a classical guitar duo arrangement of Fran√ßois Couperin‚Äôs Les Vieux Seigneurs (‚ÄúThe Old Lords‚Äù), bringing the elegance and grandness of French Baroque keyboard music to the warmth of two guitars. The performance highlights Couperin‚Äôs refined phrasing, ornamentation, and expressive dance-like character in a clear, beautifully blended duo interpretation. There are a lot of trills, slurs, hammer ons, and pulls offs in this Baroque style of music.

Fran√ßois Couperin (1668‚Äì1733) was one of the most influential French Baroque composers, known for his refined harpsichord works, expressive melodies, and distinctive ornamentation style known as agr√©ments. Serving as organist at the Chapelle Royale in Versailles, Couperin blended French and Italian musical traditions with a delicacy and elegance that defined Parisian Baroque aesthetics. His keyboard collections, Pi√®ces de Clavecin, remain a cornerstone of early keyboard repertoire and showcase his mastery of nuance, color, and character pieces.

Les Vieux Seigneurs (‚ÄúThe Old Lords‚Äù) comes from Couperin‚Äôs series of character pieces‚Äîminiatures that portray moods, personalities, or scenes through subtle harmonic color and precise ornamentation. This arrangement for classical guitar duo preserves the original harpsichord texture while taking advantage of the guitar‚Äôs warmth, articulation, and expressive blend. The interplay between the two guitars highlights the elegant counterpoint and courtly character that make Couperin‚Äôs music timeless.

Fran√ßois Couperin was a French Baroque composer, organist and harpsichordist. He was known as Couperin le Grand ("Couperin the Great") to distinguish him from other members of the musically talented Couperin family.

videos.title: Carcassi Etude 3 Op 60 ‚Äì Classical Guitar Recording
videos.description:
This guitar study works on bringing out a melodic soprano and bass voice against the less important inner voices (alto and tenor). Make it sing well basically. This video and music is perfect for someone just starting out playing classical guitar.

Matteo Carcassi Etude Study Exercise 3 Op 60 in A Major ~ Performed by Brian Streckfus 

Matteo Carcassi (1792‚Äì1853) was an influential Italian guitarist and composer of the early Romantic era, best known for shaping the foundation of modern classical guitar technique. His studies, etudes, and solo works remain essential learning material for guitarists worldwide. Carcassi‚Äôs music blends elegant melody, clear phrasing, and approachable technical challenges, making his repertoire ideal for both developing players and advanced musicians seeking expressive Romantic style.

Born in Florence and active in Paris, Carcassi became one of the leading guitar virtuosos of his generation. He toured across Europe, taught extensively, and published numerous compositions that balanced musicality with technical development. His most famous work, the ‚Äú25 √âtudes, Op. 60,‚Äù is still considered a cornerstone of classical guitar pedagogy, offering a progressive path through melody, arpeggios, scales, and important right-hand techniques.

Carcassi‚Äôs writing features:

flowing, vocal-style melodies

elegant harmonies influenced by 19th-century Italian lyricism

idiomatic guitar writing that fits naturally under the fingers

well-balanced √©tudes that strengthen technique while remaining musical

Today, Matteo Carcassi is celebrated as a key figure in the evolution of classical guitar repertoire, bridging the gap between early classical styles and the expressive Romantic tradition. His pieces ‚Äî including studies, preludes, and dances ‚Äî are performed around the world by students, teachers, and concert artists alike.

Carcassi 25 Melodious Progressive Studies

Matteo Carcassi (Florence, 1792 ‚Äì Paris, 16 January 1853) was a famous Italian guitarist and composer.

videos.title: Metal Guitar Arpeggio Sweeps !
videos.description:
Metal Electric Distorted Guitar Arpeggio Sweeps shred in A Minor performed by Brian Streckfus. Real time speed and slow motion. Tutorial, Demo, how to sweep, learn

This chord progression is a sequence in A minor, just the chords are giant:
Am add9 (i)
Dm add 9 (iv)
GM add 9(VII)
CM add 9 (III)
FM Maj7  (VI)
B dim7 (iidim7)
G# dim7 (viidim7).....or one could use E Maj (V)

Up a forth down a fifth forever in chord form. This is an etude to me, I don't take it too seriously, I would just like my sweeps to be as silky as possible.

Software/Equipment Used:
Logic Pro X
iMovie/Final Cut Pro
Korg, D888 Digital Studio
Boss GT-8 Guitar Effect Processor 
Sony Handycam CX190
This is an Ibanez Gio. It's one of the nicest Gio's of seen though they don't even make them this nice anymore, I forget the serial number. It has a floating bridge floyd rose tremolo and pickups designed for metal unlike the Gios Ibanez makes now. I like to use light gauge strings.

videos.title: Carcassi Study Etude 2 op 60 TURNED INTO A Tremolo Exercise
videos.description:
Matteo Carcassi Study Etude 2 ( In A minor but I'm sounding in G minor ) turned into a "pami" Tremolo Exercise performed by Brian Streckfus.

This is not how Carcassi wrote it. If you would like to see the actual version please watch my other Carcassi Etude 2 video. True, this isn't historically accurate but at the end of the day it is an etude, so I'm a little bit more about didactic purposes than entertainment or historical accuracy purposes when it comes to Carcassi, though the pieces do still sound beautiful. 

Why change the arpeggio pattern? To work on right hand technique basically. There's at least a hundred ways to arpeggiate a chord, so why work on just one way for five years? Might as well change it up to get more out of the etude. 

Matteo Carcassi (Florence, 1792 ‚Äì Paris, 16 January 1853) was a famous Italian guitarist and composer.

videos.title: Carcassi Etude 2 op 60 ‚Äì Classical Guitar Recording
videos.description:
Matteo Carcassi Study Etude No 2 Classical Guitar performed by Brian Streckfus from Carcassi 25 Melodious Progressive Studies

This study is an arpeggio and tremolo exercise.

Matteo Carcassi (1792‚Äì1853) was an influential Italian guitarist and composer of the early Romantic era, best known for shaping the foundation of modern classical guitar technique. His studies, etudes, and solo works remain essential learning material for guitarists worldwide. Carcassi‚Äôs music blends elegant melody, clear phrasing, and approachable technical challenges, making his repertoire ideal for both developing players and advanced musicians seeking expressive Romantic style.

Born in Florence and active in Paris, Carcassi became one of the leading guitar virtuosos of his generation. He toured across Europe, taught extensively, and published numerous compositions that balanced musicality with technical development. His most famous work, the ‚Äú25 √âtudes, Op. 60,‚Äù is still considered a cornerstone of classical guitar pedagogy, offering a progressive path through melody, arpeggios, scales, and important right-hand techniques.

Carcassi‚Äôs writing features:

flowing, vocal-style melodies

elegant harmonies influenced by 19th-century Italian lyricism

idiomatic guitar writing that fits naturally under the fingers

well-balanced √©tudes that strengthen technique while remaining musical

Today, Matteo Carcassi is celebrated as a key figure in the evolution of classical guitar repertoire, bridging the gap between early classical styles and the expressive Romantic tradition. His pieces ‚Äî including studies, preludes, and dances ‚Äî are performed around the world by students, teachers, and concert artists alike.

Matteo Carcassi (Florence, 1792 ‚Äì Paris, 16 January 1853) was a famous Italian guitarist and composer.

videos.title: C Whole Tone Ambient Creepy Jam Backing Track with Guitar Scale Chart
videos.description:
PLEASE READ DESCRIPTION FIRST FOR TIPS:

Six Note Scale: (A=440) C D E F# G# A# C
OR
Solfedge: Do Re Mi Fi Si Li Do
OR
Numbers: 1 2 3 #4 #5 #6 8

Tips:
1. Do not feel rhythmically obligated to do anything or have a strict tempo as click tracks will not work with this. Notes spaced far apart and not in time sounds fine since this pitch collection invokes a sense of timelessness and a lack of direction anyways. I did it without a click track on purpose. 
2. Do not feel melodically obligated to do anything. This pitch collection is keyless and ambiguous so there are no tendency tones. Therefore, you can play a note and not feel obligated to go anywhere with it unlike major and minor scales. Basically, take your time and be confident in what note you hit because every note will sound like the beginning and ending to something at the same time. It is nearly impossible to be "wrong" just as long as you hit these notes and your instrument is tuned in standard tuning A=440.
3. Listen to composers like Claude Debussy or Oliver Messiaen to get a sense of this avant-garde impressionistic style. This is the "time warp" scale so imagine time no longer mattering as you improvise this pitch collection. It's also a meditative and transcendent scale since there are no problems in the harmony when using this pitch collection like there would be in tonal music so relax...
4. Only 12 frets are needed to be shown since the pattern repeats exactly again for the next 12 frets (frets 13-24). 
5. If you play bass ignore the two thinnest strings or IM me and I'll send you a bass scale chart.
6. Whole tone scales have many enharmonics, which mean different names for the same sound. This scale could also be called D, E, F#, G# or A# whole tone scale. This is why it is a part of Messiaen's Modes of Limited Transposition because if you try and transpose this scale it often ends up being the same thing. For example, C Whole Tone scale (C D E F# G# A# C) is the same thing (has the same notes) as D Whole Tone Scale (D E F# G# A# C D).
7. After you understand the previous point, you will notice that there are really only two different kinds of whole tone scales not twelve. You either start on C and do whole steps forever or start on C# and do whole steps forever, those are the only options, everything else will lead to a transposition that has the exact same notes. Basically what I'm saying is to learn C and C# whole tone scales, the other ones are theoretically redundant (much like you don't need to learn the "fake" key of Cb major, that's just B Major). 
8. C# Whole tone scale is the EXACT opposite notes of these.
9. The scale pattern is visually staggered except between the B and G strings. Do you see the symmetrical patterning on the fretboard? That is unlike major and minor scales.

Please subscribe, share, like, etc...Thanks!

videos.title: Paganini ‚Äì Larghetto in A Major (Ghiribizzi No. 22, MS 43) ‚Äì Classical Guitar
videos.description:
Niccol√≤ (or Nicol√≤) Paganini (27 October 1782 ‚Äì 27 May 1840) was an Italian violinist, violist, guitarist, and composer. He was the most celebrated violin virtuoso of his time, and left his mark as one of the pillars of modern violin technique.

Niccol√≤ Paganini (1782‚Äì1840) was an Italian violin virtuoso and composer whose legendary skill reshaped Romantic-era performance and technique. Although best known for his groundbreaking violin works, Paganini also wrote for the guitar and frequently composed chamber pieces that feature the instrument. His collection Ghiribizzi (MS 43) contains 43 short pieces for solo guitar, written in a charming and accessible style that contrasts with the extreme virtuosity of his violin caprices.

Paganini spent a significant portion of his life playing guitar privately, often composing at the instrument rather than at the violin. The Ghiribizzi were written for a young student around the early 1820s and explore lyrical melody, elegant phrasing, and light virtuosity within a classical style. Ghiribizzo No. 22 (‚ÄúLarghetto in A Major‚Äù) is a graceful miniature that highlights Paganini‚Äôs melodic gift, gentle harmonic movement, and intimate writing for the guitar‚Äîshowing a softer, more poetic side of a composer famous for technical brilliance.

Today, Paganini‚Äôs guitar works are valued for their charm, clarity, and insight into his musical language. They provide accessible pieces for students while remaining expressive and artistically appealing for performers. This recording of Ghiribizzi No. 22 presents the Larghetto‚Äôs singing melody and expressive Romantic character in a clean classical guitar interpretation.

Paganini Larghetto A Major Ghiribizzi 22 M. S. 43 Classical guitar arrangement performed by Brian Streckfus.

MS 43

videos.title: La Canci√≥n del Emperador (Mille Regretz) ‚Äî Luis de Narv√°ez | Classical Guitar
videos.description:
This is classical guitar music that sounds like ancient vocal chanting. It also has that renaissance castle lute music vibe, epic and majestic. This video features La Canci√≥n del Emperador (Mille Regretz) by Luis de Narv√°ez, one of the most iconic works of the Spanish Renaissance vihuela tradition. This classical guitar interpretation highlights the expressive polyphony.

La Cancion Del Emperador (Song of the Emperor) A.K.A. Mille Regretz (a thousand regrets)
Composers: Luys De Narvaez Granada (1526-1549) / Josquin Des Prez (1450-1521)

‚ÄúLa Canci√≥n del Emperador‚Äù is one of the most famous pieces by the Spanish Renaissance composer and vihuelist Luis de Narv√°ez (fl. 1526‚Äì1549). It is his celebrated intabulation of Mille Regretz, the melancholic chanson traditionally attributed to Josquin des Prez, one of the greatest composers of the Renaissance. Narv√°ez‚Äôs arrangement appears in his landmark 1538 publication Los seys libros del Delph√≠n, the earliest printed collection of vihuela music and one of the foundational sources of Spanish Renaissance repertory.

Mille Regretz was famously known as the favorite song of King Charles V, which is why Narv√°ez titled his arrangement ‚ÄúLa Canci√≥n del Emperador‚Äù ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Emperor‚Äôs Song.‚Äù Narv√°ez transforms Josquin‚Äôs vocal polyphony into a beautifully ornamented instrumental setting, preserving the expressive four-voice texture while adding characteristic vihuela embellishments. The music is deeply lyrical, filled with subtle dissonances and poignant cadences that reflect the chanson‚Äôs theme of sorrow and longing.

Narv√°ez was one of the most innovative musicians of his time, known for his use of variation technique, ornamentation, and advanced contrapuntal writing. His works significantly shaped early plucked-string repertoire and influenced generations of lute and guitar composers. Today, La Canci√≥n del Emperador remains one of the most performed pieces from the vihuela tradition, cherished for its emotional depth and its exquisite blend of Spanish Renaissance artistry and Franco-Flemish polyphony.

Performer: Brian Streckfus

Originally written for Vihuela. Six course Vihuela F# Tuning from thickest to thinest strings:
E
A
D
F# (G is standard guitar tuning)
B
E

Then put a capo on the third fret for a more historically accurate pitch range. Basically you have to play the F# string a fret higher than normal since it is not G. Notice at 4:17 it takes 4 fingers to play a C Major shaped chord.

Luis de Narv√°ez (fl. 1526‚Äì49) was a Spanish composer and vihuelist. Narv√°ez was very highly regarded during his lifetime, particularly for his vihuela playing; he was reported to be able to improvise four parts over another four at sight. His son Andr√©s also became an accomplished vihuelist.

Johann Sebastian Bach (31 March [O.S. 21 March] 1685 -- 28 July 1750) was a German composer and musician of the Baroque period. He enriched established German styles through his skill in counterpoint, harmonic and motivic organisation, and the adaptation of rhythms, forms, and textures from abroad, particularly from Italy and France. Bach's compositions include the Brandenburg concertos, the Mass in B minor, The Well-Tempered Clavier, two Passions, keyboard works, and more than 300 cantatas, of which nearly 100 cantatas have been lost to posterity. His music is revered for its intellectual depth, technical command, and artistic beauty.

videos.title: T√°rrega ‚Äî Marieta & Gran Vals (Classical Guitar Performance)
videos.description:
This live performance in a theatre features two of Francisco T√°rrega‚Äôs most beloved classical guitar pieces: Marieta (Mazurka) and Gran Vals. These performances highlight T√°rrega‚Äôs expressive Romantic lyricism, Spanish dance influence, and elegant guitar writing.

This video presents two iconic works by Francisco T√°rrega: Marieta (Mazurka) and Gran Vals, performed on classical guitar. These pieces showcase T√°rrega‚Äôs hallmark blend of Romantic expressiveness, Spanish dance rhythms, and beautifully idiomatic guitar writing that remains central to the instrument‚Äôs repertoire.

Francisco T√°rrega (1852‚Äì1909) is widely regarded as the father of modern classical guitar technique. His lyrical miniatures, expressive phrasing, and refined harmonies helped elevate the guitar from a salon instrument to the concert stage. Marieta (Mazurka) reveals T√°rrega‚Äôs mastery of elegant melodic writing and subtle rhythmic charm, while Gran Vals captures a lively, dance-inspired character ‚Äî and is famously known for containing the four-note motif later adopted as the Nokia ringtone.

T√°rrega‚Äôs influence continues through generations of guitarists, and his works remain essential for students and performers alike. This recording offers a clear and musical interpretation of two of his most enduring compositions.
