videos.title: Luis Mil√°n ‚Äî Pavane No. 5 from El Maestro (Classical Guitar)
videos.description:
This video features ancient lute-sounding music: Luis Mil√°n‚Äôs Pavane No. 5 from his 1536 collection El Maestro. Mil√°n was one of the most influential vihuelists of the Spanish Renaissance, and his pavanes are known for their elegant counterpoint, modal harmony, and expressive melodic lines. This performance highlights the refined, courtly character of the work while bringing its Renaissance textures to life on modern guitar. The music invokes the sounds of ancient Gregorian chants. I remember Luis Mil√°n because his works are some of earliest examples of guitar tablature.

Mil√°n‚Äôs El Maestro is the earliest printed book for the vihuela and includes some of the first written instrumental lessons in European music history. His pavanes remain favorites among guitarists for their beauty, clarity, and historically rich style.

Spanish Early / Renaissance Music

Luis Milan was a Spanish Renaissance composer, vihuelist (a forerunner to the baroque guitar), and writer on music. He was the first composer in history to publish music for the vihuela de mano, an instrument employed primarily in the Iberian peninsula and some of the Italian states during the 15th and 16th centuries, and he was also one of the first musicians to specify verbal tempo indications in his music.

videos.title: Ponce ‚Äî Prelude in F‚ôØ minor (Classical Guitar)
videos.description:
This performance features the Prelude in F‚ôØ minor by Manuel Ponce, one of the most important Mexican composers for classical guitar and a close collaborator of Andr√©s Segovia. Ponce‚Äôs Prelude blends Romantic lyricism with expressive harmony, making it a beloved and atmospheric work in the guitar repertoire.

Brian Streckfus performs Prelude in F# minor ( I or VII in some editions ) by Manuel Ponce at Cohen Davison Family Theatre, Peabody Conservatory, Baltimore, MD. Junior Recital

Manuel Mar√≠a Ponce Cu√©llar (8 December 1882 -- 24 April 1948) was a Mexican composer active in the 20th century. His work as a composer, music educator and scholar of Mexican music connected the concert scene with a usually forgotten tradition of popular song and Mexican folklore. Many of his compositions are strongly influenced by the harmonies and form of traditional songs.

I am rerecording this video on March 29th, 2015. I will probably make this video unlisted in the coming months but still on my channel.

videos.description:
Visually Learn how to read sheet music for beginners. How to Read Sheet Music For Guitar and Piano 1.2

Had to redo this one, hopefully it is all around better and the resolution is clearer. Don't be afraid to pause or slow down the video to take notes as there is a lot to take in.

Includes:
Notes
Rhythm
Composers indications
Clefs
Rests
Ties
Dots
Accents
Fermatas
Time Signatures
24 Key Signatures
Chromatic Scales
Enharmonics

-Different kinds of of music notation (Sheet music vs Lute/Guitar Tablature) 
-What do music symbols mean (treble clef, bass clef, time signature, meter, whole note, half note, quarter note, 8th note, 16th note, composers indications, etc.)
-12 Notes in the music system (chromatic scale)
-Scales are combinations of intervals between the octave.
-An example of a 7 note scale starting from C without any accidentals is C Major
C D E F G A B

videos.title: Leo Brouwer - Etude 2
videos.description:
Leo Bouwer Etude 2 Estudio Sencillo Coral Lento performed by Brian Streckfus

Juan Leovigildo Brouwer Mezquida (Born 1939) is a Cuban composer, conductor, and guitarist. He is the grandson of Cuban composer Ernestina Lecuona Casado.

This piece has quartal harmony as opposed to tertian harmony. D G B (100% 133% 166%) is the most stable chord in this piece as opposed to D F# A (100% 125% 150%). Quartal harmony is the less common, but still stable division of the octave. Tertian harmony is what most western music uses (chords built on thirds).

Tertian harmony: Do Mi Sol (100% 125% 150%)
Quartal harmony: Do Fa La (100% 133% 166%)
Quintal harmony: Do So Re (100% 150% 212.5%)

videos.title: Ear Training ‚Äì Interval Identification with Visual Representations
videos.description:
IMPORTANT: Please read description first for tips!

The Idea behind this is that you use common jingles to help you remember musical intervals and I use pictures and relate them to sound to help you remember them. It's synthesia! The mixing of senses!

Remember, you can slow down the video by clicking the gear by the playback bar.

Songs to Help you remember intervals: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rVyzzCijXSA

It also reminds me a bit of the PAO (Person, Action, Object) memory trick a little bit.http://mnemotechnics.org/wiki/Person-Action-Object_(PAO)_System

Ear Training Lesson #2 (Unison, M3, P4, P5, M6, Octave) - 6 Intervals Total
Name                | Scale Degree # |   Solfeggio
P1 (Unison)               (1-1)                 Do-Do
M3 (Major Third)        (1-3)                 Do-Mi
P4 (Perfect Fourth)    (1-4)                 Do-Fa
P5 (Perfect Fifth)       (1-5)                 Do-Sol
M6 (Major sixth)         (1-6)                 Do-La
P8 (Octave)               (1-8)                 Do-^Do

Unison - Same Note (From Previous Lesson)
Major Third (Ascending) - "o when (THE ^ SAINTS) come marching in..."
Major Third (Descending) - Nelson Laugh (Simpson's) or Doorbell
Perfect Fifth (Ascending) - Main Star Wars Theme
Perfect Fifth (Chord) - Stereotypical rock chugga-chugga power chord
Octave (Ascending) - "(SOME ^ WHERE) over the rainbow..."

ALL the Intervals in this Lesson:
Descending Major 3rd (75%) - Door Bell/Nelson Laugh 
Ascending Major 3rd (125%) - Oh When The Saints
Perfect 4th (133%) - Wedding March "Here Comes the Bride"
Perfect 5th (150%) - Star Wars Theme/Rock Guitar Power Chord
Major 6th (166%) - NBC Theme
Octave (200%) - Somewhere Over The Rainbow

videos.title: Ear Training ‚Äì Interval Identification (P1, M3, P5, Octave)
videos.description:
A demo of Ear Master ear training program. I give advice on how to have better ears as. a musician. This is a beginner friendly music lesson because it starts at the beginning of ear training: intervals. After many years of doing this I have realized I should teach the first lesson with extremely consonant intervals and extremely dissonant intervals so that confidence can be boosted.

Songs to Help you remember intervals: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rVyzzCijXSA

Remember, you can slow down the speed by clicking the gear by the playback bar or stop the video if you need more time.

Ear Training Lesson #1 - Interval Identification - 
Name                | Scale Degree # |   Solfeggio
P1 (Unison)               (1-1)                 Do-Do
M3 (Major Third)        (1-3)                 Do-Mi
P5 (Perfect Fifth)       (1-5)                 Do-Sol
P8 (Octave)               (1-8)                 Do-^Do

Here is what I use or think about when trying to remember what sounds like what:
Unison - Same Note
Major Third (Descending) - Nelson Laugh (Simpsons) or Doorbell
Major Their (Ascending) - "o when (THE ^ SAINTS) come marching in......"
Perfect Fifth (Ascending) - Main Star Wars Theme
Perfect Fifth (Chord) - Stereotypical rock chugga-chugga power-chord.
Perfect Octave (Ascending) - "(SOME^WHERE) over the rainbow...."

videos.title: Bach Cello Suite No. 3, Allemande (BWV 1009) ‚Äî Classical Guitar Recording
videos.description:
This video features J.S. Bach‚Äôs Allemande from Cello Suite No. 3 (BWV 1009), arranged and performed on classical guitar in a 2013 recording. The performance highlights the suite‚Äôs flowing dance character and Bach‚Äôs rich counterpoint, adapted naturally for solo guitar.

Johann Sebastian Bach (1685‚Äì1750) composed the Six Cello Suites during his time in K√∂then, and they remain some of the most iconic works written for any solo instrument. The Allemande from Suite No. 3 (BWV 1009) is a flowing, noble German dance, filled with elegant melodic lines and subtle harmonic motion. Its linear writing adapts beautifully to classical guitar, allowing the performer to bring out the inner voices and expressive contours of Bach‚Äôs phrasing.

This 2013 classical guitar recording presents the Allemande with a focus on clarity, tone, and dance-like pulse. Bach‚Äôs music has long been a cornerstone of the guitar repertoire, thanks to Andr√©s Segovia and later guitarists who shaped the instrument‚Äôs Baroque tradition. This movement remains a favorite for students, performers, and listeners who appreciate Bach‚Äôs blend of structure, beauty, and expressive depth.

J. S. Bach - Cello Suite III: Mvnt. II. Allemande performed by Brian Streckfus on the classical guitar.

Johann Sebastian Bach (1685-1750) was a German composer, organist, harpsichordist, violist, and violinist of the Baroque period. He is one of the last prominent composers to write music for the lute.

videos.title: E Minor Aeolian Backing Track ‚Äî Ambient Jam with Guitar Scale Chart
videos.description:
This ambient E minor Aeolian backing track is perfect for guitar improvisation, modal practice, and creating expressive melodic ideas. The video includes a clear guitar scale chart so you can visualize the mode while you jam.

This video features an ambient E minor Aeolian backing track designed for guitarists who want to improvise, explore modal sounds, and develop stronger phrasing in minor keys. The included guitar scale chart makes it easy to visualize the E Aeolian mode (natural minor) and follow along while practicing melody, technique, and creative ideas.

The Aeolian mode is one of the most expressive minor scales in modern music, widely used in rock, metal, film music, ambient genres, and lyrical improvisation. This track provides a warm, immersive soundscape that works beautifully for beginners learning the scale and advanced players experimenting with modal color, tension, and release.

üé∏ Key: E Minor (Aeolian)
üéº Included: Guitar scale chart
üåå Style: Ambient / atmospheric / chill
üé∂ Use for: Improv practice, soloing, warm-ups, melodic creativity, lesson material, and background music for guitar sessions.

E Minor - G Major  (E aeolian mode - G Ionian mode) Backing Track

Ambient, sad, echoey backing track/jam

Scale diagram from GuitarMasterClass.net (educational use). Their comprehensive library of chords and scales is really nice, and its free!

1. Only 12 frets are needed to be shown because the pattern just repeats from frets 13 to 24.
2. The four different scales are all the same notes they just start and end on different notes. This is a nice guitar trick because it helps you to learn the fretboard better as long as you realize what the "real" key is. Example, you can play G Major to E Minor but "G" is a sad note (b3) and not the tonic. 
3. Blue notes are the tonic notes and therefore they tend to resolve musical sentences with an answer.

This video features a classical guitar performance of Adelita by Francisco T√°rrega, one of the most lyrical miniatures in the Romantic guitar repertoire. This recording highlights the expressive phrasing, warm tone, and delicate rubato that make the piece a favorite among students and concert performers.

This video features a classical guitar performance of Adelita by Francisco T√°rrega, one of the most beloved miniature masterpieces of the Romantic era. Known for its gentle melody, expressive phrasing, and elegant harmonic language, Adelita remains a favorite among classical guitarists for its emotional depth and intimate character.

Francisco T√°rrega (1852‚Äì1909) is often called the father of modern classical guitar technique, shaping the instrument‚Äôs expressive possibilities and leaving behind some of the most important works in the repertoire. His music blends Spanish folk color with Romantic lyricism, producing timeless pieces like L√°grima, Adelita, Capricho √Årabe, and Recuerdos de la Alhambra. T√°rrega‚Äôs writing is beautifully idiomatic, making his works essential for developing tone, phrasing, and expressive control.

This recording of Adelita offers a clean, musical interpretation suitable for listeners, students, and anyone studying T√°rrega‚Äôs style. Enjoy this classic gem of the guitar‚Äôs golden age.

This recording highlights the expressive phrasing and flowing arpeggios that make Carcassi‚Äôs Op. 60 studies timeless for both students and advanced guitarists. This is a famous tremolo exercise.

Matteo Carcassi (1792‚Äì1853) was an influential Italian guitarist and composer of the Romantic era. His 25 √âtudes, Op. 60 remain foundational in modern guitar pedagogy, blending musicality with technical development. Study No. 7 in particular teaches smooth arpeggio control, tone shaping, and dynamic balance ‚Äî making it a favorite for teachers, students, and performers around the world.

His Study No. 1 in C Major, Op. 6 No. 8 is one of his most beloved etudes, celebrated for its flowing arpeggios, balanced phrasing, and beautiful simplicity that makes it ideal for both developing guitarists and seasoned players looking to refine tone and right-hand technique.

This recording presents Sor‚Äôs Op. 6 No. 8 with clean, transparent tone and classical phrasing, offering a clear demonstration of the right-hand patterns that define this study. Because this piece appears in nearly every major classical guitar method, it is a favorite for students and teachers looking to strengthen control, evenness, and musical expression.

videos.description:
Classical guitar performance of Bach‚Äôs Bourr√©e II from Cello Suite No. 3, BWV 1009 ‚Äî a lively Baroque dance movement arranged with clear phrasing, warm tone, and expressive articulation.

Experience Johann Sebastian Bach‚Äôs Bourr√©e II from Cello Suite No. 3, BWV 1009, arranged and performed on classical guitar. This movement showcases Bach‚Äôs brilliant counterpoint, rhythmic energy, and elegant dance character, all adapted to the expressive timbre of the guitar.

Bach‚Äôs Cello Suites (composed c. 1717‚Äì1723 during his K√∂then period) remain some of the most beloved works in the classical repertoire, and guitarists have embraced them for their clarity, polyphonic potential, and technical depth. This arrangement highlights the warm resonance and expressive phrasing unique to classical guitar, while staying faithful to the character of the original cello version.

Johann Sebastian Bach - Cello Suite III: Bourree II (BWV 1009) performed by Brian Streckfus on the classical guitar. 

Recorded: Jan, 2013.


Johann Sebastian Bach (1685-1750) was a German composer, organist, harpsichordist, violist, and violinist of the Baroque period. He is one of the last prominent composers to write music for the lute.

videos.title: Guitar Improvisation Classical Ambient Pentatonic All minor Keys
videos.description:
Classical Guitar Improvisation going through every key. 

Even if you don't like the aesthetics of this backing track it is still useful because one works on all keys in a six minute period. Rather than working on all keys song by song which would take 3 minutes x 24 = 72 minutes to play 24 popular music songs in the respective keys. See what I'm saying? It is just a very efficient way to work on key fluency, which is important for every musician, especially when working with other musicians.

Dorian mode, windy, melancholy, pentatonic, music, instrumental, jam, improvise, jazz, etude, training, learn, how to
Performed by: Brian Streckfus

videos.description:
Romantic, windy, floaty, romantic, classical, guitar, music. One of my first videos over a decade old now. I've come a long way...please check out my newer videos.
Francisco Tarrega - Lagrima performed by Brian Streckfus
Fransico Tarrega (1852-1909) Spanish composer and guitarist from the Romantic era.

**Francisco T√°rrega (1852‚Äì1909) was a Spanish composer, guitarist, and teacher widely regarded as the father of modern classical guitar technique. His expressive miniatures, lyrical melodies, and idiomatic writing transformed the guitar from a salon instrument into a respected vehicle for concert performance. T√°rrega‚Äôs music blends Romantic-era lyricism with Spanish folk color, creating some of the most beloved works in the classical guitar repertoire.**

Born in Villarreal, Spain, T√°rrega studied both guitar and piano from an early age ‚Äî a combination that profoundly shaped his harmonic language and approach to voicing on the guitar. After advanced studies at the Madrid Conservatory, he became one of Europe‚Äôs leading guitar virtuosos, performing widely and attracting a circle of dedicated students. His teaching laid the foundation for the 20th-century classical guitar tradition, influencing great players such as Miguel Llobet and, indirectly, Andr√©s Segovia.

T√°rrega composed dozens of pieces that remain cornerstones of the guitar repertoire, including *Recuerdos de la Alhambra*, *L√°grima*, *Adelita*, *Capricho √Årabe*, and numerous preludes, mazurkas, and √©tudes. His works are celebrated for their warm expressiveness, elegant phrasing, and clear, singing melodies that sit naturally under the fingers.

Today, Francisco T√°rrega is recognized as one of the most important figures in guitar history. His music continues to be performed by students, teachers, and concert artists around the world, and his technical and musical ideas remain central to classical guitar pedagogy.

Composer: Francisco Tarrega

Edition: "The Complete Early Spanish Editions - In Reprints of the Originals" (Chanterelle) 
Unaltered reprints of the 48 original editions dating from 1909-1920.
